38735194.review:
SEUM is just the right amount of fiendish difficulty to satisfy that old school kick while still retaining a very low level of bullshit. It's quite literally platforming in an engine that feels extremely close to Quake 3 with some really cool aesthetic choices.

+Optimized well, very friendly to toaster ovens
+Soundtrack is metal af
+Level design is pretty ambitious, even in earlier levels
+Constantly present leaderboards
+Still actively supported by the devs
+Steam workshop and a really simple to use level editor

tl;dr it's 1999 style platforming with a very solid soundtrack. 9/10.

36111574.review:
Great game.
The levels design is creative and challenging but fair.
The background and level elements are hell-ish, so they fit in great with the theme of the game.
Music also fits the setting perfectly and it's chosen carefully to not be a distraction.
It's quite easy to pick up, but very hard to master. You will find that out if you try to get a certain position in the leaderboards. You can also compare your time with your friends which is a great addition.
Having the option of watching other player's playthroughs of a certain level is also a nice touch, you can use that to improve your time.
That being said, there are a few levels that don't feel fair but it's only about 4 of them out of 100 or so.

Take Lovely Planet, up the gameplay speed but ditch the BS twitch shooting, give it a kickass soundtrack, allow the player to change FoV and you're about halfway to SEUM, a game in which you'll have fun blasting through your PBs like never before.

35499398.review:
这是一款极富个性的第一人称超能力跑酷[spoiler]受苦[/spoiler]游戏

[h1]在这里，你可以体验到：[/h1]

贯穿流程的重金属音乐带来的节奏感

超过一百个各具特色的关卡设计与简短顺畅的跑酷游戏体验以及停不下来的魅力

极其丰富的收集要素与难度颇高的时间挑战还有强迫症的噩梦

多种不同模式的游戏体验

90年代的传统游戏画风


[h1]标准的复仇剧情展开[/h1]

主角坐在家中惬意的喝着啤酒，突然遭遇恶魔SATAN破墙而入，不但抢走了他家中的库存啤酒更砍下了他的一只手，主角在怒而反击后将砍下的恶魔右手拼装到了自己身上，然后带着这只能发射火球的麒麟臂前往地狱，在看完了这段充满了美漫风格的剧情介绍后，我们的主角MARTY开始了捅穿地狱和夺回啤酒的冒险


[h1]传统的WASD操作[/h1]

地狱跑者的角色操作模式与传统的FPS游戏一脉相承，WASD控制方向，空格跳跃，鼠标控制射击，左键是射击小火球，右键则是在得到了超能力后的特殊应用

除此之外，最常用的快捷键则是负责快速重新开始的R键、退回选关界面的M键和查看回放的TAB键
[spoiler]反正你R键会是按的最频繁的！	[/spoiler]


[h1]随处可见的重金属元素[/h1]

当体验过游戏后，玩家一定会对地狱跑者中那充满了节奏感与爆发力、足以让人产生破坏欲望的BGM留下深刻的印象，开发者从一开始就将地狱跑者标榜为重金属风格游戏，从界面UI到地狱建筑的式样，无一不体现出这种硬派作风，在评测中也受到了许多重金属爱好者的一致追捧


[h1]单纯而紧张的跑酷过关[/h1]

地狱跑者的游戏方式简单明了，只要你冲到传送门便能通关。同时在每个关卡中，恶魔会设下电锯、岩浆、地刺等各种机关障碍来妨碍玩家的前行，作为凡人的MARTY一旦被击中，自然是毫无商量的秒杀。但同时玩家角色也能利用透明石阶、跳台等一系列环境元素和使用例如发射火球、时间倒流等超能力手段帮助自己避开各类危险，成功抵达传送门

在地狱跑者的单机剧情模式中，每九关普通关卡与一关BOSS关卡、一关额外关卡组成了一层游戏内容，而在每挑战完毕一关后，关卡选择界面也会更新玩家的挑战记录与目标达成状况

作为一款拥有数量过百挑战关卡的游戏，地狱跑者的每一关都可以用短小精悍来形容，大部分关卡更是将过关时间控制到了10秒之内，可以说在地狱跑者的每一关中，过关时间都是第一要素，系统会在屏幕上方显示计时条来形象的告诉玩家距离目标的剩余时间，而玩家则需要利用一切可利用的因素将过关时间压缩至最短来达到系统要求


[h1]仅供参考的系统路线与排行榜上的大神表演[/h1]

虽然系统中对玩家的过关时间要求以完成金色骷髅作为标准，但是由于有排行榜的存在，便促成了人与人的互相伤害。而地狱跑者最有挑战性的内容便在于玩家的路线并不是一味的跟随系统所提供的路线而走，最速过关没有唯一的解法，玩家的手速、反应、细节与创意都是在挑战最速路线时不可或缺的因素，可能前进路途中不经意的一次细节调整所缩短的时间便是几百名的差距所在

开发者鼓励玩家之间的最速竞争。为此在游戏中，当玩家在系统规定的时间内顺利抵达终点后，时间记录便会同步到排行榜上给出名次，同时也会开放玩家查看自己与其他玩家通关回放的权限，来让玩家了解自己与大神的差距所在来优化过关路线再次挑战然后更加绝望


[h1]翻箱倒柜找啤酒[/h1]

在地狱跑者的每一个关卡中，除了以过关时间来作为标准获得的金银色骷髅外，还有我们主角此行的目标---被夺走的啤酒，而啤酒则被恶魔藏在了每一关的犄角旮旯里，玩家则必须绞尽脑汁来将整个关卡翻箱倒柜来找回自己的啤酒（在额外关卡中隐藏道具从啤酒换成了培根）

唯一值得庆幸的是找啤酒的旅程并不需要和通关在一起完成，只要找到啤酒。即使下一秒挂掉也算玩家已经完成了目标

除此之外，在部分关卡中还设置有顶峰挑战的旗帜标记，作为给予那些挑战自我的爬山党勇攀高峰的奖励


[h1]更多模式[/h1]

除了拥有一百多关官方关卡挑战的单人模式（扩展游戏是官方在游戏发布后的新增关卡）外，游戏还提供了可以选择将一层十关合在一起，单纯计算时间来挑战排行榜的竞速模式、在背后血腥滚轮追赶下只能向前冲的无尽模式以及可以加载玩家自制MOD来进行游玩的工场模式。进一步拓展了地狱跑者的可玩性


[h1]结语[/h1]

地狱跑者作为一款复古跑酷游戏，与他所标榜的重金属风格一样，虽然并不一定能受到所有玩家的追捧，但是却可以提供给那些嗜好收集、挑战高难度的玩家们一个充满创意的舞台。对于这些喜好硬派游戏作风的玩家来说，地狱跑者的确可以称得上是不可错过的作品～

34759233.review:
SEUM is one of those weird games where almost everything when horribly horribly right. Essentially Super Meatboy meets Metalocalypse, SEUM (briefly) tells the story of a Marty, a metal fan, who cut off Satan's hand, duct-taped it to his own arm, and descends into the depths of hell. 

The game is just plain fun. That's what it is. It's fun. The game's description warns that you'll lean toward your screen as you play and its totally true. You'll tense up, feel the rush of hot air, and immerse yourself into the heavy metal landscape. 

Similar to Super Meatboy, SEUM initially gives levels that show you the ropes before testing your skills. However, where Super Meatboy continued to introduce new concepts and challenges into the late game, SEUM has a comparatively limited toolbox.This makes the late game of SEUM into a puzzle platformer with an emphasis on speed. You solve the puzzles first, then come up with the fastest way to do it. While not especially unique (Quantum Conundrum did it), the game has a great simulated movement that puts you right in the moment. 

Speaking of speed, I really appreciate how the game handles competitive speedrunning. Every run you make is logged into the system. Once you beat the "Uber" time, you can instantly see how the best people in the world run it. The great thing is that many levels have a second secertish way of solving puzzles, but the majority of levels can just barley be solved using the standard route if you have enough dexterity, training, and time. 

As for art design, the soundtrack is complementary and makes the game seem faster than it really is. Satan and Marty talk to each other from level to level and have some fun quips. The devil hand looks awesome and has fingernails made of stone. The backgrounds of hell are kind of hit or miss. 
You have 3 main regions: Generic lava landscape, dark green pit of bubbling acid with giant cheesy skeletons in cages hanging from the ceiling, and what I can only describe as Dethklok's wet dream. While the first and last areas are mostly fun to look at, the green pit isn't appealing to the eye and doesn't invoke images of hell. Additionally, there's really nothing to look at in the background. No tortured souls, no demons, etc. There's not a single full character model in the entire game. The last level in the story has you fighting Satan in one of the most anti-climactic ways possible. I really would have liked to see a Super Meatboy-esque race between Marty and Satan rather than another 90 second puzzle level. 

Still, that small gripe with art direction aside, I found SEUM to be an addictive and relaxing experience. An arcade game you can play for 5 minutes or 5 hours and hardly tell the difference.

SEUM : Speedrunners from Hell fait parti de ces jeux où les niveaux peuvent vous faire péter un câble mais vous recommencez tout de même, encore et encore, jusqu'à temps que vous réussissez... Et puis c'est la délivrance lorsque vous y arrivez !!! Quelle joie, quelle satisfaction... Puis vous continuez, et vous recommencez, etc... 

C'est un jeu de plate-formes en FPS où il faut évidemment "try hard" au moins un peu (sauf si vous êtes sacrément doué ou chanceux). Vous n'avez pas vraiment le temps de vous ennuyer entre tous les niveaux dont recelle SEUM ! 
Il y a non seulement le mode "Single player" avec 11 niveaux pour 9 étages (donc 99 niveaux + les niveaux secrets) mais aussi l'"Extended play" qui rajoute d'autres niveaux, le mode "Speedrun" qui permet de jouer les niveaux du "Single player" à la suite sans s'arrêter puis le mode "Endless" où il faut aller le plus loin possible sur un parcours infini ! 
Ensuite il y a même un workshop qui permet de jouer à des niveaux créés par la communauté ou même de créer soi-même ses propres niveaux !!!! Si franchement ça ne vous suffit pas tout ça ! :) Bref une bonne durée de vie !

Le gameplay est vraiment parfait et c'est parfaitement fluide. 

Les graphismes ne sont pas terribles mais sincèrement, c'est vraiment ça le plus important ?

Il n'y a pas grand chose à dire de plus si ce n'est... un univers bien METAAAAAL, une bande son bien METAAAAAL, un personnage bien METAAAAAL !!! 

En tout cas : je recommande bien évidemment !

Fast paced and thrilling, SEUM is a great first person platformer with an emphasis on speed above all else. Having not completed the game yet sitting around two-thirds of the way through at just finishing Floor 6, I feel I have played enough to thoroughly recommend this to anyone who is thinking of buying. It can be frustrating at times, but that only makes it all the more rewarding when you get it right. With that I will say that it probably isn't the game for everyone. Whilst the par times for the levels are generally quite forgiving and easy to meet, the domination times require a bit of both dedication and skill to get, but in the end, give the most satisfaction. Even if par is all you need to progress, I would say you should try and challenge yourself to get the domination times too as that's where I've had the most fun with the game.

Overall, I've really enjoyed SEUM thus far and haven't regretted a single minute, a definite purchase if you're interested even slightly.

Note: Bought as a part of the "Killer Bundle X" from Bundle Stars.

33381672.review:
Incredibly boring, uninspired level design, filled with gimmicks and long, straight, entirely unchallenging corridors; sluggish, unresponsive controls, partly because in this game a mid-tier video card can't achieve 60 fps on anything but the lowest graphics settings; very generous target times, that require little skill and innovation to beat. 
These things come together to severly hinder the mastery of control that is usually crucial in speedrunning, the ability to execute insanely precise tricks consistently to get a better time. Again, since the level design is so bland you will have a hard time finding any levels where such skills are needed, but it still feels frustrating while playing.

The aesthetic of the game is well done, music and presentation fit together to create a fast paced, metal experience, the macho quips between the guy and Satan are funny, if you like that sort of stuff.

Overall, it's a speedrunning game for casual players that's not very fun to actually speedrun. If you're looking for a First Person Shooter to speedrun that has precise controls and requires and facilitates absolute mastery of them I can recommend Lovely Planet instead.

32413106.review:
[h1]SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell[/h1]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell is a first person 3D puzzle platformer which puts you in the shoes of a trucker whose beer was stolen by a demon and now it is up to him to go to hell and back to get his beer back. SEUM is like a birthchild of Devil Daggers and Super Meat Boy where the controls are slick and tight and there is a huge sense of accomplishment after completing something.

SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell has bite sized levels and a fast paced control scheme. You start off with simple stages which let you get acquainted with the game. Each level has a time limit within which it needs to be completed and a secondary time limit to beat for extra points. The game slowly introduces you to its different mechanics and gives you various powers like throwing fireballs, teleporting and anti gravity etc, all of which need to be used simultaneously whenever the game requires. 

There are slight puzzle elements present inside some levels which require a bit of thinking but the game never leaves you entirely clueless as to what to do like the teleporting orbs which are present when the game requires you to teleport and you cannot teleport without acquiring one. The game requires you to have a very accurate sense of movement though and being a first person game it is slightly difficult to keep a lookout for everything. But just like Devil Daggers you need to rely on your instincts while learning from the previous errors you made. 

SEUM has an excellent method of keeping you invested in the loop of dying and repeating. If you die, you are immediately thrust back into the game without going through much hassle. If you win a game you are being shown your replay in the background while looking at the victory screen giving you an insight on the level and places where you could have gone faster.

 The game is quite difficult and while you die a good number of times, it never induces the feeling of rage quitting. The reason for that is the short amount of time you invested in that level till that point. There will be moments where you will pass on a difficult section only to feel overconfident and fall while trying to cross the simplest of platforms but that is all part of the process in Speedrunners from Hell.

But the game’s greatest sense of achievement comes when you find a hidden way or discover an alternate path to cut the total time by some margin. While the total time will most probably be affected by only a couple of seconds, that can make you score much higher on the leaderboards. The game shows you the leaderboards right on the finish menu and it feels really good when you move up a few ranks to break the top ten. 

The level designs are excellent and there are quite some levels where you don’t land on the platforms at all. SEUM is all about beating your own time set while not trying to get impaled by the spikes or falling into the fiery depths of hell. It keeps things simple enough for the right time to let you feel comfortable to the game and still just be difficult enough to keep your adrenaline pumping.

 Its premise is silly enough and unlike some other games, it never takes itself too seriously which works in its favour. It is unlike anything I have played for quite some time and overall its gameplay is very solid.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]

SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell has a pretty generic visual aesthetic when it comes to depicting hell. The fiery pits of lava, the tall cliffs standing beside you, dark buildings ripe with spikes and other stuff like that. But the game never feels too cheap or unpolished with the help of some neat little effects like the gesture of hands whenever your fireball activates a required puzzle lever.

 There are low res textures present everywhere but they don’t bother much because of the breakneck pace of the game. Unless you stand and try to take a look at its environments, SEUM does not do much wrong visually.

[h1]Sound[/h1]

Some solid Heavy metal music leads an adrenaline pumping soundtrack which compliments the gameplay of SEUM perfectly. It gives you the rush required to jump over the difficulties and never lets go of the hold on you. It is one of those soundtracks which is incredibly repetitive and forces its way into your ears but never gets old to listen to. 

[h1]Overall[/h1]

SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell is an incredibly fun title which gives you the everything you want from a game like this. Tight controls, solid level design, difficult but rewarding platforming and a badass heavy metal soundtrack to top it all off. It is completely worth the price of admission and easily worth a recommendation.

[h1]Rating:85/100[/h1]

31502867.review:
SEUM is one of a kind. It takes the concept behind platformers, puzzle games, and speedrunning then sends it to hell where you, Marty, have to retrieve your beer after Satan broke into your house, removed your hand, and stole all of your alcohol. You've vowed to avenge what you have lost and must run through the many of cirlces of hell with nothing but the hand of Satan and a kick a.ss metal soundtrack. 

Mechanically this game is fantastic. The movement is incredibly well tuned and the level design is very creative and well designed. In addition to speedrunning through various traps and obstacles, you are also given powers. You can shoot fireballs, reverse gravity, teleport, spawn platforms, and reverse time. This adds another dimension to the complexity of the already intricate levels. It's a very satisfying game to play, especially after you spend hours perfecting one level and finally make a flawless run. You can also compare leaderboard rankings with others and friends. The top 10 on each course will go down into the "Pit of Infamy" at the end of the Season to concrete your success in SEUM's history. There are also various hidden collectibles, pathways, and QR Codes throughout the game as well as a level editor with workshop support.

[b]Conclusion [/b]

If you are into speedrunning, skill games, puzzles and problem solving, are a completionist, level creator, or just love improving your skills I can't recommend this game enough. There's not many games like this, and much less so that executed it so well. The options menus are fairly in depth between graphics, controls, and various preferential options. It's very stable, lacks bugs or quirks almost entirely, and overall feels great to play. Performance is smooth and I have not ran into any FPS issues or stuttering. The level design is incredible and there's around 15 hours worth of courses, depending on how quick you're able to get through them, not including workshop maps and collectibles. There are also Extended play (pretty much free DLC), Speedrun mode, and a procedurally generated Endless mode. I paid full price for this game and I have loved every minute of it, even when bashing my keyboard in from frustration. If you're into this kind of game, I believe $15 to be more than fair.

31089481.review:
I wasn't aware of SEUM up until I had played its demo (now removed from the Store). In less than one hour, I was completely convinced that this game had immense potential, so I added it to my wishlist and waited for a sale. Six months later, here I am writing a review for it.

SEUM is a first person platformer where you have to complete each level as fast as possible. Featuring a leaderboard system, you can track your times, your friend's and the worldwide records for every level. The scores are reset on every season, to make sure the top scores are fair without fixed exploits. It is technically an incentive to come back to it once in a while in case being on top is something you love.

Running on the Unity engine, the game does not look spectacular or revolutionary but what matters is that it plays wonderfully. Controls are simple but tight, and movement feels perfect for the genre. All controls are rebindable in case you want to customize them. Graphical options are very limited which is disappointing, but you can adjust the FOV from about 60 to 140, which in my opinion is a crucial option in a game like this, despite the max value being a little too much!

The first levels are fairly simple which mostly serve to introduce you to the mechanics, but the difficulty surely starts to increase on the third floor. With an impressive variety in level design and level variety, every level feels completely different from the others. That said, repetition doesn't feel frustrating in this game, it is the only way to learn and progressively get better. In total, there's about 150 levels on this game to be beaten, about 25 of them added in expansion packs (labeled as Extended Plays), completely free of charge! If you even want more levels, SEUM features Steam Workshop support and has a level editor to create your own demonic creations with ease! Within every level there are 2 different times to beat, and a beer hidden in it. Obviously, to get 100% completion all of this criteria is required. These beers do get very challenging to find on later levels! I have to admit the Steam discussions and guides surely gave me a hand. There's just tons of content in this game to discover and play through. About 10 secret levels, 12 bonus levels and 10 rituals to complete, which unlock 10 more secret levels.

The music in this game despite being very short and limited, is great! The tracks are either rock or metal songs with no vocals, that will have you humming along while dying over and over again. At the time I did the Hardcore Speedrun, I had it turned off to listen to my own music, but bear in mind I had about 25 hours clocked in at this point. There's some great tunes in this title, definitely a game to NOT mute while playing!

Five powerups may be present in the levels: Teleport, Anti-Gravity, Split, Spawn-Platform and the Booster. The last one is just a temporary speed boost so it's not like the others. You can have one powerup equipped at a time, and this means you have to plan your strategy on levels with various powerups. Bear in mind you spawn with no powerup, it must be picked up every time. There's definitely a learning curve in each of these powerups and it will take a while to master them.

If the clock ticking on each level isn't enough for you, there's also an Endless Mode that randomly generates an infinite hall with traps with a deadly machine right behind you to make sure the player doesn't slow down. Run, Marty, run! And if the Endless Mode is still not enough, you also have a Speedrun mode where you can speedrun entire floors at a time... or even the whole bloody game from start to finish! Not to mention that there is an option to enable the Hardcore Speedrun mode in which you have to complete the whole game without dying. It was a tough and lengthy challenge, but completing felt overwhelmingly satisfying. Still not enough content to convince you? Well then... just go find the secrets and Easter eggs scattered around!

It took me 35 hours to complete everything in the game, including the Hardcore Speedrun. Of those 35 hours, none of them were tedious, I cannot find a section of this game that I utterly hated or despised for being too hard, too frustrating or just boring... except Level 70 - Lamb of the Spit, of course. It is safe for me to say that SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell is a formidably astonishing gem in the gaming industry. That said, it's completely worth getting it even at full price for it's excellent blend of platforming and fast paced action.

30721734.review:
Mmmm... this one's fine, I guess. There's a lot about it that's just "fine".

The aesthetic is okay at first but gets old quick and the texturing is pretty low res & kind of ugly. And the only variation is the background and color changing a bit. The music's all alright too, as an avid metal listener it's... well it's very video gamey for sure, kind of has an old school metal vibe to it but with a much more modern sound. I don't mind it but some of the tracks that get played the most can get tiresome after a while. The repeated voice clips also get tiresome really fast, and honestly the protagonist isn't particularly likeable. 

Gameplay-wise then. I don't really care for the arcing fireball. I'd rather just have a straight shot. The levels are designed around it, sure, but still. Not a huge fan. And the teleport is kind of a cool mechanic but can be pretty wonky sometimes as well. The powerups in general are all pretty cool though, yeah, and they help with exploration. The secret hunting in this game actually takes up more time than playing the levels normally, or at least it did for me; there's one collectible in every level, a good number of secret levels as well, and some weird riddles that I honestly couldn't be bothered to figure out myself.

And as for the main gameplay itself... yeah, it's alright. They keep the levels pretty diverse, though a few do go on too long and overstay their welcome. And the mines are a bit iffy, feel like they have a bit too big of a blast radius even when you blow them up yourself. The game keeps itself pretty fast paced for the most part, though there are times that the momentum in the game goes against the platforming they want you to do, and there's a bit too much tiny platforms & narrow walkways for my liking, it leads to level design that doesn't flow as well as it could. But on the whole I enjoy playing these levels, yeah.

That's just the thing. There's nothing outstanding about this game. It's just very "fine" all around. If you're really into speedrunning and precision games you'll probably get more replay value out of this one than I did but there's not much here that makes me really want to come back t it, but I can't say I didn't enjoy playing it either. It's a very fine game that kind of hides how vanilla its gameplay is with the over-the-top aesthetic. Get it on sale I'd say, full price probably not.

I beta tested the game, and despite my insistence at buying it, the devs didn't answer (they answered everything else just not that part). So I got it for free. But then I bought it anyway and gifted it to friends, so there, I win in the end!

Review:

This game is amazing. It is challenging, well made, fun. Some level designs are really top-notch and deserve praise. The mood is more doomy than Doom 2016.

The game works in short, addictive loops, and is fun even at low level play. I am not a really good gamer. However, I can still manage scores good enough to keep playing. There are also different challenges, such as finding hidden beers, which are a welcome change of pace after spending 30mn perfecting 8 seconds.
Which is not to say that the game doesn't have much to offer for people who like a challenge. You can spend hours working at shaving off that little additional second or millisecond.

Technically, the game is responsive and I could detect no input lag, but there was some frame dropping despite my pc being quite decent. I had to set the resolution slightly lower than HD to get really fluid FPS; I personally don't care in the slightest, but some people might be bothered by that (To note, I didn't notice such drops on Linux, so maybe it has to do with my Windows setup).

In short, what you see in those videos is exactly what you're getting. No false advertising, no misleading blurb, no miscommunication; those dudes and dudettes know what they produced and what they're selling. If you like what you're seeing, definitely go for it, you won't be disappointed.

Games that range in the same category for me (in terms of fun, replayability, and refinement): Meat Boy, Devil Daggers, Super Hexagon, VVVVV, Doom (93), Quake, N++

Edit: Forgot to mention the soundtrack! Top notch soundtrack

29138526.review:
Martyt alakítjuk aki békésen sörözget, mikor beállít hozzá a Sátán, (huncut módon egy régi heavy metal bakelit lemezt csúsztat be, hogy beengedjék) lenyúlja a söröket és levágja a méltatlankodó Marty jobb kezét, aki cserébe a lemezzel meg lesurikenezi a távozó démon mancsát. Főhősünk viszont kemény redneck legény, némi lánc, szigszalag, levágott démonkéz segítségével pótolja a hiányzó jobbost és utána ered a pokolba, hogy visszaszerezze a söröket(és még sok minden mást is).

9 szinten - és még egy kicsin - és az ott található pályákon kell átverekednünk magunkat a fináléig. A fő játékmenet marha egyszerű: juss el minden pályán a portálig a szintidőn belül. Jó azért ennél bonyolultabb játszva mivel a kezdeti cső egyenes pályák után már minden féle hangulatos akadály állja utunkat. Vannak felvehető powerupok mint pl teleport, antigravitációs, platform kilövő etc amiket a felvett pótdémonkézzel tudunk használni. Ez egyébként tud tűzlabdát is köpni amikkel különböző lámpákat/pokolbéli triggereket tudunk meggyújtani.

Kiegészítő feladatként érdemes megkeresni és begyűjteni a pályán eldugott söröket, jutalmul minden szinthez kapunk egy bónusz pályát - jó itt már szalonnát kell szereznünk, a szintidők mellett. Azért vannak még vicces plakátok, poénok eldugva, valamint mindenféle elátkozott QR kódot lehet megkeresni - ezek olyan érdekes weboldalakra visznek minket, mint pl. egy heavy metal videóklipp a youtubeon etc. Ja és még vannak más gyűjthető dolgok is, de egyelőre legyen ennyi elég. :)

A pályák elég rövidek, pár tíz másodpercesek csak, kivéve a szintek főnök mapjait, azok olyan egy-fél percesek. A szintidőket elsőre nem lesz könnyű teljesíteni - szinte mindig van vmi trükk - de hát ez egy ilyen móka, egyébként kétféle is van belőlük: az ezüst akinek sikerült, és az arany (ubertime) ez az advankedebb megoldásokat szorgalmazóknak. Van pályánkénti világranglista, ha megszerzed az aranyat, megtudod nézni, hogyan teljesítették a legjobbak vagy a barátok. Az arany szintidőket meglépni egyébként nem nehéz, ha tudod már a megoldást, de a top 10-ekbe bekerülni adamantiumgyémántkemény módon elviselhetetlen, konkrétan a lélegzetvétel is számít, miután speedrunner módon felkészültél egy adott pályára. Például az egyik pályán 42 ezred van köztem és az első között de közöttünk vannak még vagy kilencvenen.

Grafika teljesen jó, olyan mintha a Quake kihordta volna a Hexen gyerekét, a zene heavy és metál, Marty és a Sátán folyamatosan nyomja a dumát a pályákon, attól függően éppen mi hogy sikerül persze.

Van még egy kezdetleges level editor, amivel megálmodhatjuk a saját szadi pályánkat, ezeket megtudjuk osztani(workshop) a többi emberkével, baráttal ahol szintén saját ranglista készül a futott időkkel. Ez egyébként olyan jó móka, hogy többet toltam már vele mint a rendes játékkal.

Ajánlott.

29101281.review:
"SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell" is a first-person platformer where your entire goal is to reach the end of the level as fast as possible.

As its subtitle suggests, the gameplay is heavily calibrated towards taking every risky move and trick imaginable in an attempt to slice off as many precious milliseconds from your record as you conceivably can. And in that sense, SEUM does its job wonderfully.

Your character is capable of doing three things: running, jumping, and throwing infinite amounts of fireballs. And that's really all you need, since as the levels go on, the game throws more and more obstacles and unusual level designs at you, always requiring you to think fast and learn from your mistakes. Much like Super Meat Boy, you are going to die a lot and keep respawning again and again until you manage to nail a level, the only difference being that you have a keyboard shortcut with which you can respawn instantly.

You are going to have to deal with lots of spikes, swinging blades, rings to jump through, moving platforms, sawblades, and so on. On top of that, you eventually get ahold of four different powerups, each adding a new angle to the gameplay. The controls are very tight and everything is very tightly designed, making it a joy to perfectly nail some of the more risky maneuvers. Almost every time you fail, you can tell that it's your own fault, and you immediately take note of the things to improve on during your next attempt.

The game's humorous take on the theme of hell also works very well and sets up a lovely tongue-in-cheek atmosphere, where you feel that you are some beer-chugging badass who jumps across hell like it's nothing, all while bobbing his head to the awesome heavy-metal soundtrack. The surrounding hellish environments are really nice to look at and provide a nice backdrop for the action happening in front of you.

Really, the only things I could complain about are largely nitpicks. For instance, the graphics seem a little dated - the game appears not to use normal maps or shadows, so everything is kinda flat and covered by global, uniform lighting. On top of that, the developers' idea of creating a wall seems to be taking a rectangle and slapping a wall texture onto it - and while they try to cover that up with some extra decorative bits, sometimes this graphical simplicity becomes rather apparent, to the point that there were times where I felt like I was playing a Gmod map or something. I realize that this is probably because they wanted the graphics to not get in the way of the gameplay, but still...

One other complaint I would have is that while the Level Editor is quite easy to learn and use, it's still missing some important features at the time of me writing this review - such as [i]drag select[/i]. I mean, really?!

But despite this, SEUM is an awesome game and easily one of the best games I bought myself this Christmas. If you like fast-paced platforming, then this is a game for you. Especially because it's far easier to master its controls than Super Meat Boy's.

29011399.review:
[h1]Хэви-метал, Prepare to die, содомия - добро пожаловать в SEUM![/h1]

Тупоголовый черт врывается и разносит дверь щепки одного дома, где проживает персонаж по имени Марти. Возмущенный поведением демона, наш протагонист начинает прописывать серию комбо-ударов по красной физиономии нежданного "гостя". В итоге отродье погибает, но герой в драке теряет руку и идет в гараж, где еще толпа исчадий ада крадут ящик с пивом. В ярости оторвав руку одному из бесов Марти приделывает ее к себе и отправляется в ад, чтобы вернуть себе свое пиво и надрать задницу нечестивым силам зла - вот вкратце весь сюжет игры.

Игровой процесс представляет из себя [b]смесь головоломки, платформера от первого лица, и одновременно раннера[/b](в каком-то смысле) с видами на адские достопримечательности. Арсенал героя не богат - прыжок, да демоническая рука для разрушения и преодолевания препятствий, однако время от времени герою на различных уровнях будут давать бонусы вроде остановки времени и контроль над гравитацией. Задача игрока состоит в том, что ему предстоит преодолеть множество смертельных ловушек за определенное количество времени под драйвовый рок. 

Сами же испытания в меру сложные, интересные, рвать себе задницу не обязательно, но если вы какой-нибудь там ачивмент хантер, то приготовьтесь взять пластырь и смазку для вашего ануса, и еще ведро успокоительного на всякий случай, ибо дело предстоит не из легких.

[i]Из минусов могу отметить лишь корявую чувствительность управления, в частности клавишу пробел - не всегда может сработать клавиша прыжка(чаще всего подобное происходит при комбинации двух клавиш одновременно).[/i]

К слову о музыкальном сопровождении, про которое я оставил пару строчек выше - оно драйвовое, заводное, и отлично дополняет атмосферу происходящего в игре, с этим Иван Джиц справился на ура. Любопытно представить, что же Undercode сможет сотворить для грядущего шутера Serious Sam 4, который вскоре могут представить на выставке E3 2017.

[h1]По игре могу сказать пару вещей - это веселый треш-платформер с отличным саундтреком(в хорошем смысле данного слова), который поможет вам убить время весело и с удовольствием \m/[/h1]

[h1] Linux Version Review [/h1]

One of the biggest surprises for me in 2016, with a simple premise. Satan stole your beer, but you have his hand. Go through trials using different powers to get your beer back. Along with shooting fireballs, you can teleport, rewind, reverse gravity, and create platforms, depending on the level. And man some of these levels are hard as hell (pun sort of intended), so playing a level to try to beat it over and over, finding the secret beer or bacon (there is one in every single level), and optimizing your time to get into the top 10 best times is going to make you sink a lot of hours into this game (I've sunk about 12 hours as of writing this and I've almost done with the main campaign, but just started on the next episode). I also really love the metal-and-hell aesthetic, and the art style fits very nicely into that. 

In a recent update, they've released a level editor for the community to create and share their levels, which was the final push for me to pick this up, because now there is virtually endless replay value, in playing over 200 community made levels and create your own masterpiece. 
EDIT: Linux version does allow you to use the level editor. 

Thank you for putting this on Linux!!

For those whom have played gmod's deathrun, this is very similar, but it is just you running from the beginning to the end with many ways to die... and a rather strict time limit.
For those whom haven't, this game is rather simple. Run, very fast... don't fall, dont step on spikes or fire or lava or bombs or saws.
In addition to the good ol, run super fast gameplay, there are also hidden items in every level to collect which unlocks even more levels which unlocks more things to unlock!

I've played a few of these types of games and have always been let down one way or another... but this specific one, just feels so right. It is of no understatement to remark that of all my more recent purchases, this one keeps drawing me back to it over and over.
Endless mode adds a bit more extra to the game, but once you start to reconize all the chunks, it begins to feel like a super long level.
The level editor is extremely easy to use, just simply placing down pieces and lining them up as you wish, along with being able to test the level at any time as long as you put the required pieces in. Sadly, as of this moment, it doesn't feel like there is a large playerbase trying the workshop levels just yet, but that doesn't stop me from having fun making each level that I do.

SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell é um jogo de estilo [i]Parkour / 3D[/i] que irá re-moldar os conceitos que muitos estilos de jogos semelhantes seguem. A história começa quando um rapaz, que estava bebendo e assistindo televisão, recebe uma calorosa visita do Inferno. Um portal do inferno se abre em sua casa, e dele sai um demônio que decepa o braço do rapaz; furioso o homem corta o braço do demônio também, que volta para o inferno. Com sede de vingança, o rapaz pega o braço do demônio decepado e o toma para sí, adentra no portal do Inferno para caçar o demônio.

A trilha sonora do jogo é bem frenética, apesar de os gráficos deixarem um pouco a desejar. Detém uma mecânica simples, afinal o objetivo do jogo é atravessar o mapa até chegar ao final, passando por diversos puzzles realizando muitas manobras. Possui uma grande quantidade de mapas, e uma surpresa lhe aguarda em cada um. Como se já não bastasse o número de mapas, o jogo contém Steam Workshop para edição de níveis criados pela comunidade.

No começo achei o jogo muito fácil e pensei que era bom em jogos de Parkour, mas depois de jogar um pouco este inocente pensamento foi para baixo. O jogo começou a ficar muito difícil e tive que tentar várias e várias vezes alguns mapas para poder completar a tempo. Gostei muito da soundtrack pois ela remete um estilo de Rock, e o protagonista pode fazer um gesto de rockeiro com as mãos durante o mapa, é muito engraçado. Algumas vezes eu ficava bem perdido na travessia do mapa, quando chegava ao final recebia uma mensagem bem grande "VOCÊ NÃO CHEGOU A TEMPO" que me desanimava pois pensava fazer tudo certo.

[h1]+Pros[/h1]

+Gráficos
+Soundtrack
+Steam Achievements
+Steam Trading Cards
+Steam Workshop

[h1]-Cons[/h1]

-Não há tradução para Português
-Não tem suporte para Controle de Console

27997965.review:
SEUM: Speedrunners From Hell is one of the most rewarding indie games I've played in a while. I fell in love with it during the first half hour of gameplay. It's like Portal by way of Iron Maiden, combining spatial puzzle solving with break-neck speeds and fast-twitch reflexes. Every level is worthy of multiple attempts because they present two different challenges: one of planning, and another of execution. Each level is a puzzle, and as you attempt them over and over you notice places where entire milliseconds can be shaved off through the use of a different technique. It gives you the "AHA!" moment that the best puzzle games offer, but in a context where you're too busy having fun to feel like an idiot for not noticing the solution sooner.

Unlike Portal, the difficulty ramp in SEUM is perfectly balanced. I was a couple of hours into the game before I really started to sweat the latest levels, but by then I had already gone back and repeated all my previous levels in order to get better times and move up the ranking system. If you find yourself getting stuck on a particular challenge then there's always a huge amount of other content waiting to be challenged.

The best part of the game is the sense of achievement you get when you perfectly execute a run and manage to increase your ranking on that particular level by shaving 200 milliseconds off your previous best time. There're so many great levels that I want to constantly revisit and practise in order to inch closer to the top 100 rankings. My favourite level so far is #36, Parachute. The moment at which I got the 71st fastest time on the leader board might be my gaming highlight of the year. I was so exhilarated by the sense of speed, tension and satisfaction that I could hardly drag myself away from the game.

The soundtrack is an original composition of heavy metal tracks that are all of a really high quality. They're all instrumental pieces with an emphasis on roaring guitar solos that keep up the tempo and push the player forwards, deeper into speedrunning hell.

The game has some flaws. The graphics are straight from 2010 and look like something I'd expect from a Source mod. Very few textures in the game hold up on close examination and the graphics settings are lacklustre. Humour abounds in SEUM but only half of it really hits for me, and when I've played the same level 300 times back to back, hearing Satan repeat his funny one-liner to taunt me starts to lose its charm. The powers the player uses during the game all have the potential to be frustrating to use, depending on the level. And that's about it; a few nit-picks but nothing worth crying over.

This game is advertised as being "the first heavy metal speedrunning game", which sounds like a joke until you play it and realise what an excellent idea a heavy metal speedrunning game truly is. For me, it's a real under-rated classic, a better tribute to heavy metal than Brutal Legend could ever be, and well worth the £10 price tag.

27983845.review:
SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell (SEUM) est un excellent jeu de plateforme 3D à la première personne. Bien que ponctué d'humour, ce n'est pas le scénario de ce jeu restera dans les annales mais bien la nervosité de son gameplay. Petit topo : notre personnage, buveur millénaire de binouses bon marché se fait arreter par Satan et est obligé de traverser les 9 étages des enfers pour retrouver sa liberté (petite référence par ailleurs à la Comédie Humaine de Dante et aux 9 cercles de l'enfer)

Doté d'une courbe de difficulté bien évaluée, SEUM est un jeu long en casu (environ 10 à 15h pour le 666%) et exigeant pour les speedrunners. 
Parlons maintenant de speedrun. Ce jeu est bien évidemment fait pour les speerunners. Les niveaux individuels offriront du défi à ceux qui souhaitent avoir leur nom dans le top 10. Il est aussi possible via le mode "Speedrun" de faire le plus vite possible les 9 étages indépendants ou l'intégralité du jeu.
Le timer interne facilite les runs mais l'absence d'option sur celui ci (obtention de nos Sum of Best ou des temps du WR par exemple).
En terme de technique, les speedrunners apprécieront la présence de nombreux tricks (Corner Boost, Slope Boost, Wall Stop) mais aussi de petits glitchs et de nombreux skips.

Je finirai enfin par remercier les développeurs pour la qualité de leur travail et pour leur réactiver et leur écoute sur le Discord officiel du jeu (que je recommande vivement au nouveau joueur par ailleurs ;) )

Bilan: 9/10

- un classement mondial pour chaque niveau où chacun peut admirer les replays des meilleures runs

26375786.review:
I just saw the word "speedrunners" in the name, so I decided, why not? And then I bought it. And, you know...

[i]I don't regret a single thing![/i]

This game combines what I like most in games, every major thing. First of all, it's a speedrunning game. You [b]have[/b] to be fast in order to progress, you have to find creative and unusual ways of completing a level, most of these ways being mostly [b]intended by developers[/b]. This game basically teaches you how to speedrun, which is, as for me, the greatest game idea ever.
Secondly, Doom + Duke Nukem + references = the atmosphere of this game. I don'teven really kno how to describe it; the brutal protagonist Marty who seems to only care about his beer, Satan, hell... This atmosphere, in couple with the level design, is the greatest element combination I have ever seen. Huge thanks to developers for doing this in particular.
Thirdly, gameplay. Not only do you have to run fast, you also have to aim well and calculate... Everything. From physics to positions of moving objects. There are also a few power-ups you can collect in a level, which you have to be smart with, too.
Fourthly, secrets. Just running fast isn't enough to progress, you need to collect secrets in basically every single level, and the further down to hell you are, the harder it gets. I love both speedrunning and exploring, which depends on the game, so I always wondered if it was possible to somehow combine these two elements in one game. Well, I guess this is the game to accomplish that.
Fifthly, global leaderboards and replays. If you somehow manage to complete the level fast enough to beat the par time, you'll be granted an ability to see how others completed the level, which is an amazing learning opportunity for beginners and not-so-experienced players (AKA noobs), and an excellent competition for pros.
Sixthly, achievements. I can't say a lot about them because I haven't achieved a lot, but from what I've seen, they are hilarious and overall well-made. Unlike in most modern games, you don't get achievements for every step you make, you have to work hard to unlock most of them.
Seventhly, the soundtrack. It's [b]awesome[/b]. I'd say, it's just the soundtrack I want in most FPS games, but it fits this one particularly well. If usually I start playing some YouTube video or some music from a social network, for this game, I actually close my browser and enjoy the game soundtrack. Just like in the older, classic games which are now legends.

Overall, I can say that this game just brings back the nostalgia, still maintaining the drive and the speed. The gameplay is extremely entertaining, the level design is quite simple yet pleasing to the eye and bringing a feeling of overall brutality of what's happening. I don't know how to describe it, really, but need I? Try it out for yourself! I give this game 10/10 without hesitation, and I know for sure that this is what I'll be playing for the next month or so. Since Doom and Duke Nukem are now legends, I want SEUM to be a legend, too
Cheers and huge thanks to Pine Studio,
kyoob

26058422.review:
This game put a smile on my face from the start: decent metal track, nice small touches in settings menu (difficulty setting made me laugh - in sync with audio cue). Then came the time for the first level and I've dropped my smile. Having some background in original forms of parkour/speedruning/trickjumping (like q1-q3, promode, defrag) it isn't easy to accept that walking is faster than jumping. So far I've tried just 2 levels (will try more later) but being forced to walk from corner to corner (trying not to clip any) in straight, shortest possible, path without jumping is a bit painfull (also makes replays rather dull and bigger part of levels obsolete). Movement is simplified: air control involves +forward and steering with mouse (strafe keys do work but so far are useless). Nice thing is that you can control somehow the strength/height of jumps (and therefore time loss) plus double jumping is possible of some steps/rings etc (but again going high and loosing time). Ability to run replays from leaderboard w/o leaving given lvl is a great addition.
 So far i guess I could recommend it to peeps w/o knowledge of trickjumping mentioned earlier, especially if they're into rock/metal culture. If you have tasted more challenging, advanced forms then perhaps only if you're bored - demo's available. Bouncing is what Tiggers do best! For better or worse, I am one.

Edit: In later levels "puzzle" element seems to play bigger role (including top players exploits), but rest stays the same.

(No neutral button and overwhelming proportion of positive to negative reviews force me to choose negative)

25795189.review:
SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell is a very fast, first person platformer, starring heavy metal, the Devil, beer and lots of spikes.

If you enjoy beer more than life itself, then you should relate to the poor fella in this game. One night he was drinking his beer, enjoying his time, when – long story short – a series of unfortunate events unfold, leaving him with the Devil’s hand and no beer. This forces him to set on an epic journey to take back his beer from Satan. I’m very good at explaining stories, aren’t I? In SEUM you play as the man who has lost all he loves (his beer), and who will do anything to get it back – even if that means 1v1-ing the Devil himself, which is absolutely one hundred percent not a good idea. Unless you’re redneck Devil hand beer guy, in that case you’re good to go!

Anyway, you progress through the depths of hell, ultimately attempting to beat all 100 levels and get your beer back, whilst keeping your soul. In each level there is a set time that you must finish the level in, giving you the silver medal for the map, with an optional, quicker time, that gives you the gold medal. There is also beer to grab on each level for completionists, and once you have collected all of the beer – or as many as it says – you gain access to a bonus level on each floor. After the main game is finished there are also a bunch of extra levels on floor -9, though I haven’t been able to figure out how to get them yet.

The levels consist of lots of running, jumping and restarting. There are four powers that you can grab in the levels, one teleporting you to wherever you shoot, one reversing gravity, one making a checkpoint that you can use to go one way and activate something, then warp back to the checkpoint to save time, and one building platforms in the air for you to jump on.

Beer, hell and heavy metal are the three key elements in SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell. That last part is especially important in the game for me, because the epic riffs and solos in the soundtrack fuel my vengeance to get the poor man’s beer back, making me play ten times better. Sometimes the songs get a bit repetitive (the tracks play on a loop), but when you’re focusing on beating the levels you don’t really notice. I noticed, though, because I pick on the little things.

Being based in hell, SEUM features lots of saw blades, swinging axes on chains, and spikes, smeared with fresh blood. Creepy. In the bottom of each level there is a large pit with gigantic spikes that could impale a dinosaur. You know, the usual Satan stuff. The art style, as you can see in the images, isn’t exactly realistic, but it isn’t cartoon-like. The cutscenes, as you can also see, are comics – quite well done actually (they are animated, but you can’t see that from still images).

The dialogue is comedic, with phrases including ‘There’s nothing like a good beer,’ and ‘Damn you Pine Studio!’ Those are quotes from the playable character, but you will be saying them soon enough. The Devil also speaks, as a voice-in-your-head figure, with quotes such as ‘Yes…’ and ‘Fatality!’ Be aware, though, the game does feature strong language. I’m sure you aren’t really interested in the dialogue, but I thought I’d cover it because not many people realise that good sound effects and voice acting plays a major role in whether a game seems cheesy or not. This game makes the cheesiness of the quotes on paper sound awesome in-game, especially with the guitars going in the background.

If you like to brag about your skill, you can do that with the game’s leaderboards. It’s not as easy as it looks though, some people out there are incredibly fast!

There are two other modes besides the main story mode, one being ‘Speedrun’ and the other, ‘Endless’. Speedrun is a mode where you are pit against other players’ fastest times for a whole floor on the leaderboards, in an attempt to beat them – but as I said, it’s not easy, some people are very quick. In Endless you compete against a massive spinning spike-riddled rolling pin in a randomly generated endless map where you must reach as far as you can. The rolling pin could move a bit slower, I mean, we’re not all that fast!

One thing I would have loved is a custom level builder. The game is brilliant enough without it, but it would have been nice for the game to have just that little extra bit of community interaction.

I've had a smashing time playing this gem so far. I almost threw a brick through my computer fifty times, but I have restrained myself… mostly. It’s been a great experience, almost completely finishing a challenging game for once. I think you should all give SEUM a go, or at least try the free demo that is available to download on Steam. If you have $15 to drop for a good game that will keep you going for quite a few hours, you should definitely check out this one.

👍 SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell IS worth the US $15 it is available for.

25464031.review:
I played the demo for this game back in July and loved it, so once i had some spare money i bought the full game as well. However, after playing 10+ hours of the game, i wish i hadn't. The first few floors of the game are VERY fun, but i found that after a while of playing the aesthetic became boring to look at. Even with very similar visuals on every level i was enjoying the game a lot up until ~floor 7, at this point the game started to feel very tedious, and the longer levels started getting very annoying. Levels 80 and 81 also felt very clunky and the feeling of being able to move through the level very smoothly wasn't there anymore. I have only done the hidden ritual levels 1-3 at this point, but the third one is horrible, it has three rings spinning around very fast, so not only are you spinning, but you are spinning while trying to jump to the next ring, then on the final ring witch is spinning so fast it was making me motion sick, you have to jump from that to a non-moving platform with the end portal on it, but when you jump off of a spinning platform it flings you in the direction it was spinning, so it's incredibly hard to land there. Overall the game has a lot of content in it, but in my opinion only about 2.5 4ths of it was fun and worth doing. I do plan to go back at some point and finsih all the hidden levels and such. My final reveiw of this game is a 2/5. If you see this game on sale for ~$8 and you really like speedrunning/platforming games i would recommend buying it, however i wouldnt pay any more than $10 for it.

Edit: I forgot to mention that there were multiple levels that were very glitchy, and i was even able to go through the ground and walls on some of them.

TLDR, 2/5, dont buy for more than $10.

25113298.review:
A Headup Games karolta fel a horvát Pine Studio első nagyszabású videojátékát. A történet szerint Marty épp a reggeliét fogyasztja, miközben váratlanul kopogtat az ajtaján egy démon, aki elterelésként becsúsztat egy bakerlit lemezt. A pokoli teremtmény betöri az ajtót, lennyisszantja Marty karját és bejelenti, hogy minden sört magával visz. Ennek következtében hősünk bosszúból lecsapja az ördög jobb karját és elmenekül. Marty a garázsba siet, majd felcsatolja magának ellensége végtagját, amivel így akár képes tűzgolyókat is lőni. Egyetlen feladat lebeg a rocker szeme előtt: visszaszerezni az összes sört.

Már a [b]SEUM[/b] logójából is jól kivehető, hogy az alkotók a klasszikus Doom játékok előtt tisztelegnek – hangulatilag és (valamelyest) grafikailag egyaránt. Habár az utóbbi nem a legnagyobb erőssége eme alkotásnak, indie cím révén kicsit sincs szégyenkezni valója. A minimalista külcsín teljesen rendben van, a hanghatások pedig kifejezetten hangulatosak. Ám mégis, maga a játékélmény az, ami nagyon ütősre sikeredett. Mivel ez egy „speedrunner FPS” (már, ha létezik ilyen stílusú játék), ezért az a célunk, hogy minél gyorsabban eljussunk az elejétől a végébe.

Ellenségünk gyakorlatilag nincs. Az első néhány pályán sok akadállyal nem találkozunk, inkább csak az idővel versenyzünk, azonban ahogy haladunk az végső, 100. terep felé, egyre nehezebb feladványokat kell megoldanunk. Martyval képesek vagyunk tűzgömböt lőni, ami gyakorlatilag állandó fegyverünk: ezzel a spéci tulajdonsággal gyújthatjuk meg a pályákon elhelyezett gyertyákat, melyek ajtókat nyitnak, illetve robbanthatunk szét falakat, talpazatokat. Pályáktól függően három további speciális képességet vehetünk fel, de ezeket a golyókat, szám szerint hármat repülésre, teleportálásra vagy az idő visszafordítására használhatunk. Egyszerre egyik adottság sem lehet nálunk.

Akadnak csapdák is szép számmal, ezek pedig olyanok, mintha a Super Meat Boyból kopírozták volna át őket, viszont ezúttal belső személynézetből veselkedhetünk neki a feladványoknak. A SEUM-ban a legfontosabb a megfelelő időzítés! Szinte ki kell centiznünk minden egyes lépésünket, mert ha nem tesszük, akkor biztosan jön a semmiből egy hatalmas fűrész, hiányzó padló vagy bármilyen más hirtelen előbukkanó kelepce. A pályák persze nem kiismerhetetlenek: van közöttük olyan, amit játszó könnyedséggel kipörgetünk, ugyanakkor előfordulhat olyan is, hogy sokaik próbálkozásra sem tudunk bejutni a portálba.

Érdemes minél gyorsabban teljesíteni a pályákat, illetve minden egyes sörös dobozt felvenni, ugyanis csak egy bizonyos szint után tudunk eljutni a végső megmérettetéshez. És az sem mellékes, hogy (világ)ranglista szinten versenybe szállhatunk barátaink vagy más játékosok ellen. Megemlítenénk még a főszereplőt, Martyt, aki egy vérbeli redneck, amolyan Duke Nukem és Sam Stone szerű flegma, egoista karakter, aki frappáns beszólásaival mindig színesíti a játékélményt.

25083636.review:
[h1]Must buy at any price [✓]
Worth the money but wait for a small sale [x]
Wait for a huge discount [x]
Avoid at all costs [x][/h1]

SEUM, a game all about speedrunning, sounds odd right? a 2016 game that isn't indie scams, shooter or moba.

You might think to yourself "Why should I buy this game? Like honestly I can't speed run nor does it sound fun." well, you're wrong.

I saw this game and instantly fell in love, speedrunning isn't a game genre itself, it was a community made thing which mostly aimed at older games as they were easy to break and complete. Then Pine Studio came in, making SEUM, a one of a kind game on steam, it doesn't compare to "SpeedRunners" as SEUM was targeted for proper speedrunning.

[h1] GRAPHICS [/h1]
SEUM was made on Unity, I know a good looking and well made game running on the Unity engine.
But the graphics are unique, they aren't some triple A, 12k sony textures. But they're good enough to satisfy any player,they're simple with 2 options which are resolution and graphics preset, the game doesn't include that FXAA blur effect but instead keeps it nice and clear so speedrunners can focus on the game rather than the graphics.
It also has that old doom feel, it's set in hell with a heavy metal feel around it which sounds bad but honestly works out perfectly for this.

[h1] SOUNDTRACK [/h1]
I usually don't talk about soundtracks in games as I mute them or turn them down, I always give them a try and none have satisfied me, but then SEUM came along with it's metal, I was ready to completely mute it before even giving it a chance, I'm happy I didn't though.
Metal isn't a popular music genre, it isn't up there anymore like that cheeki breeki hardbass or pop, but should be.
Pine Studio made an amazing soundtrack not only because it sounds great, but it motivates you to keep trying to beat your records, makes you feel badass and accomplished if you succeed.

[h1] GAMEPLAY [/h1]
It's a speedrunning game, you do need to be quick, the soundtrack like I said before goes well with gameplay, you need to be very focused on every single level and there's always alot of room for improvement making me always come back to this game, yes this is a speedrunning game so it may seem short, if you try to get 100% the game will possibly take 10-20 hours at max, but don't think of not buying it for being "short", this game has replayability to every aspect, getting better times for levels, new strategies, shortcuts!

[h1] PLOT [/h1]
[spoiler]You're chilling back as a ginger man named "Marty", have a beer in your hand, watching TV until Satan walks in and takes your beer, you're like "fuck off m8 this is mine" BUT THEN, OUT OF KNOWWHERE SATAN CUTS OFF YOUR WRIST, SO YOU CUT HIS OFF! He runs away with your precious beer but Marty didn't give up, he went into his secret basement and built a new hand with satan's hand, you go into hell with a badass fireball hand and fight through it , until you reach the end.[/spoiler] [b] ENDING AHEAD [/b] [spoiler] You're there at last, level 82... "Beer Heaven" , there's some clouds...they all were special though as they had beers all over them, Marty was literally in Heaven and never left...[/spoiler]

[h1] COMMUNITY [/h1]
On steam the community seems inactive or dead, but when you get on the discord you'll find a humble and welcoming community, everyone sharing strategies, chilling out and talking with eachother, even the [b]DEVELOPERS[/b] are in the official discord server and discuss about updates, ask for ideas and even implement them!

[h1] SUMMARY [/h1]
This game feels like it had alot of effort put into it, with the whole surrounding (Hell) in combination with the music just making everything feel badass, you can rarely find some edges that shouldn't be there, but they're very rare to find.

24977506.review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

[quote] PLEASE NOTE: This review is being cast as a full review and not a first impressions review because the main bulk of the game is finished, SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell offers different modes such as Endless Run and Speedrun with mostly the same premise as the main levels offered, hence, this review is being cast as full because the main bulk of the game is complete, so please, think before you comment! Enjoy :) [/quote]

SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell is a game developed by Pine Studios and published by Headup Games

SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell is exactly what it says in the title, it is a speedrunning game that takes place in hell. You play the stereotypical hillbilly known as Marty who loves shooting stuff and of course drinking beer. One time for no apparent reason, Satan decides to pay a visit and steals your lifetime supply of beer whilst also chopping off your arm in the process

You become angry with Satan and do the same thing with him which is chopping off his arm, which for some magical reason you manage to sow onto your right arm and you get the powers that the lovely Satan has and go kick some Satanic butt

With Satan's arm you get cool powers such as teleportation, gravitation, shooting fireballs, duplication and so on and so fourth. In the 80+ levels of speedrunning goodness you use these powers to your advantage

The game is challenging and can sometimes but very rarely lead to rage and breaking of keyboards and screens but what SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell has that some other hard challenging games of this sort don't have is that it offers some kind of fulfilment and addiction, each time you complete a level in the amount of time sepcified, you feel satisfied and want to continue

There are nine levels to go through in the wonderful world of hell, each floor has 10 or 11 levels each, the tenth level is a sort of bass level which although there is no boss, it is usually the hardest level on that specific floor. The game also houses many hidden secrets and beers that if collected, after a certain amount of beers, a secret level is unlocked however you don't have to play these secret levels to complete the game

The graphics are nothing to write home about, they get the job done and are very pleasing, the little that I could look around the environemnts, they were well designed. The levels themselves are also well made and don't feel slopply made

The music too is nothing to write home about, it is the generic heavy metal style soundtrack that every game that takes place in hell does. The voice acting, although it is just two people; Satan and Marty, are voiced pretty well however I did notice sometimes the change in audio level especially with Marty, but nothing to complain aboout

The only thing I would complain about is that SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell does not offer a level editor yet (might be offered in a later update). This game could be perfect with user created levels and the Steam Workshop support. Hopefully, Pine Studios will add the ability of level editing in the coming future

SEUM: Speedrunners from Hell is hard yet oddly satisfying. Beating a level in the specified time is both amazing and addiciting to just continue playing the game. Even if you don't intend on finishing the main bulk that the game has to offer, just playing a few hours of the game can offer both enjoyment and fulfilment that only a few of these challenging games offer

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

24897377.review:
You see, this is what makes indie games enjoyable. They don't have to be overly complex and expand beyond what the game is clearly capable, resulting in a giant, potentially confusing and empty mess. All you need is a fun premise, a silly storyline just for kicks, and above all, gameplay that will leave you want to play it over and over again.

This game delivers just that. You play as a redneck/metalhead who's out to get Satan, because for some reason Satan thought it was a good idea to steal your beer. So you descend into hell, armed (heh) with a demonic arm severed from Satan himself, which shoots fireballs and can grant you several powerups such as anti-gravity, teleportation, or rewinding yourself to your last known position since you used the powerup, in order to retrieve your precious beverages.

Gameplay is simple, yet challenging. It's basically a first person platformer, and your goal is to run like hell (puns are fun kids) from point A to point B while jumping, dodging, and using various powerups in order to not suffer a fiery death, and in the shortest time possible. You can also use your demonic arm to use powerups, and to shoot fireballs to clear out mines, or trigger switches. I say simple, because you really get the hang of it after only a couple minutes in, making the game really easy to get into. The challenge comes in timing your jumping and movements exactly right in order to arrive at the goal in the shortest time possible, to top a place among the leaderboards. There is a time limit, however you don't die immediately if it runs out. Rather, you can still explore the level as you wish, however when you do reach the goal you will have to start it over because you were too slow. This looks and plays reminiscent to something like Quake, or Doom, in regards to how fast-paced it is, which gives it extra points in my book. 
The real fun comes in trying to beat your friends in the leaderboards/making a name for yourself among the top. Which is way harder than it looks.

The levels themselves start out simple, however you will have to learn to use combinations of powerups in conjunction in order to beat a level, and you will feel like a god once you successfully pull it off. There's also a wide variety of powerups, some of which can be combined in a very creative way which definitely spices up the gameplay.

So far, I am loving the atmosphere in the game. as I mentioned before, seems to take inspiration from Quake and Doom to make for a really satisfying aesthetic. The soundtrack is also absolutely great too. Nothing quite like fast-paced platforming while heavy metal plays in the background.

[h1] Conclusion [/h1]
Overall, would I reccomend it? Yes, I definitely would advise you to try it out. It's fun, is simple, and this is a shining example as to what indie games should be like. Smooth gameplay, and just letting you have a whale of a time.

10/10

24795023.review:
SEUM Is a fast paced speed runner and a platformer game combined in first person view. I think the best way to describe the game would be as the developers themselves say, Super Meat boy combined with the crazy maneuverability of Quake games. Hell (no pun intended), even the logo of the game is a straight up reference to Doom. Many concepts in this are derived from the old FPS arena shooter games and that’s a good thing. 

[u][h1]Graphics:[/h1][/u]

The game looks pretty nice to look at. Atmosphere is right on point and really feels like you’re in the depths of the earth. The game still has that old Doom/Quake/Unreal Tournament vibe in the art department. While the graphics are much improved the whole art-style is reminiscing of these incredible games. As a huge fan of older Quake and other arena shooting games I enjoyed this look of the game in SEUM. The graphics menu doesn’t have a lot of options. There’s quality presets which go from low to ultra, v-sync, resolution adjustment etc. There is field of view adjustment available too which goes all the way up to 90. Overall the game ran very smooth for me and for such a game it’s a requirement to have fast smooth action because every millisecond counts. I got over 60 FPS throughout the time I played the game.

[u][h1]Sound:[/h1][/u]

The game has pretty neat sound. As expected you will find heavy metal sound track are pretty good. Not my cup of tea but it was quite nice the ones I heard. In addition to that Satan will continuously talk to you as well, saying some stuff which can be quite funny.

[u][h1]Gameplay:[/h1][/u]

Gameplay is as simple as it can get. The level select screen starts off with you being able to select one of the 10 levels (you can choose in any order you want). You have to finish all these 10 levels in order to unlock the elevator which takes you 1 level below into the depths of hell.  When you finish the next 10 levels you get to go down another level of hell. This goes on for 100 total stages in 10 levels of hell. Naturally as you progress downwards, the levels get harder and downright brutal. Every 10th stage of a level is a boss fight. These usually require more platforming skills and are longer compared to your average stage. There are also hidden (or hard to reach) beer collectibles which you can collect as well.

When starting a stage, you cannot move unless you click your left mouse button, again, just like the arena shooters spawn mechanic. Once clicked you’re dropped in the map/arena and you have to reach your goal which is a blue colored portal. There is a timer which you have to beat in order to actually beat the stage. Although when the timer runs out, nothing happens you’re free to stay in the map and do whatever you want but when you actually get to the finishing portal it’ll say you’re too slow and to retry again. This is good to explore the map and strategize your movements, in the later levels when things get complicated, you’d need this. There’s also a sort of a 3 stars’ system, except in this you have 3 versions of Satan. Normal, flaming and super flaming Satan. The quicker you finish a stage the better your ranking. You’re also placed in the leaderboards and compare your times with your friends.


To get through the various traps, spikes, lava pits, pendulums and many other obstacles and objects your character can jump and depending on how long you hold the jump button the longer you can jump. If you want a very short jump you can just tap the button. The jump and in-air time really matters as you consistently have to use the longer or shorter jump to avoid obstacles or projectiles being thrown at you. 

Your character has a main fire ball attack. When you throw these fireballs they will travel in an arc sort of like a grenade launcher in many games. Your fire balls have many uses such as turn on fire switches which you simply shoot and they light up, these can open up gates. There are blocks which only appear when you shoot at them with your fireball later in the game. Other things such as mine bombs can also be destroyed with your fire attack. The power ups can also be picked up with your fireball.

There are many types of power ups you can pick which are required in the maps to be able to reach your goal. In the first levels you get the anti-gravity power pickup. This can make you fly so to speak. You can fly up in air by pressing the right mouse button and when you let go, you’ll fall down. Another power up is the teleportation power pick up, which throws a teleportation ball in an arc and wherever it lands you’ll get transported to that place. Right clicking again will immediately transport you to wherever the ball is in the air.

Another power up is the split ball. Upon picking up that you have the ability to split into 2 or sort of set a checkpoint of yourself and then right clicking again brings you back to the point you split off. This is used to power on switches and go back quickly or access places where you cannot go back from. E.G you have switches on the lower ground which you can jump to but cannot jump back up, so you have to rely on the split power up and set up a split point before you jump down there (an example of this can be found in the gameplay video below). Other power ups are also available such as a speed boost etc.

There are a couple of other modes as well. There’s the speed run mode which can be unlocked for each 10 levels. These are basically the same levels as the story levels but you get to speed run them. Other mode is the endless mode which is sort of like those endless runner games such as Temple Run except this is way too hard. You have a wall of spikes chasing you and you have to keep running, your score is measured in terms of the distance you travel. This mode randomly generates obstacles and throws different obstacles, spikes, pendulums and other things at you. This mode is pretty hard.

A short gameplay can be found below, please excuse the terrible aim. I played the game with in-home streaming with a regular mouse, different DPI from my main gaming mouse so things were a bit off.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=740580771

[u][b]Graphics: 8/10[/b][/u]
[u][b]Sound: 7/10[/b][/u]
[u][b]Gameplay: 9/10[/b][/u]
[u][b]Overall: 9/10[/b][/u]

[u][h1]Conclusion:[/h1][/u]

Very fun game for fans of platformer games, who like a challenge. This is basically a 3d version of Super meat boy with some elements similar to 10 Seconds Ninja X, while some puzzle elements thrown in there too which are similar to Portal or other first person puzzler games. The game is pretty good to look at and if you’re also a fan of the old Quake movements, you will like this game. It’s an homage to games such as Quake, Doom, Unreal Tournament and it does justice to them. Even though this is more of a puzzler/platformer game, it reminded me of those good old arena shooter days. Plenty of content and achievements. I was very impressed with this game and highly recommend it.

Every level is replayable at least two times since all of them offer a speed-running challenge and a optional hidden beer you can collect. The game also offers both global and fiends only leaderboards so it's easy to have a bit more fun by directly competing with your Steam friends.

I especially applaud the choice to go with a very large number of short levels. This way you still get substantial total gameplay time and in the same time you are able to get in and out the game very quickly. So SEUM can be a great way of passing time or taking short breaks.

Controls are simple and spot on.

My only suggestion would be to somehow give more feedback to the player when he bumps into a wall.

All in all a very good game worthy of your time.

24728379.review:
Just finished going through the regular levels this game had to go through. I'm not including the bonus levels on this review since I didn't collect the hidden goodies. This will be my first steam review too.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

The object of the game is simply to make it to the end of each level by making contact through these blue portals that act as a finish line. If I am not wrong there are hidden beers and among other stuff on each level that you can find if you want to look around, these will unlock bonus levels especially the ones around Floor 9. Platforming for the most part is solid, the only annoying thing I found is that jumping up through a platform section feels a bit slippery since you slide around a bit while climbing. Other than that there isn't much else to note, I am clearly not an expert on platform speedrunning but I did have a good time trying to make it through each level. You can try to achieve the best time to complete each level if your into that sort of thing, with some levels you'd be at first baffled to figure out how it was done so quickly. In conclusion about the gameplay, it's solid even if I'm not a fan of this genre.

[h1]Soundtrack[/h1] 

The music this game has to offer can get a bit repetitive even if each song is interesting and helps you keep going on each level. It's possibly something I cannot play outside of this game but the songs are good for what they are. Or maybe  I only like certain types of metal music. 

[h1]Art Design[/h1]

The environments look interesting when you spend the time looking at it. I can't go into detail because I'm not an art person but long story short the art and the look of the game does its job and I didn't notice anything bad about it.

[h1]Voice Acting[/h1]

There isn't a lot of it in this game when I went through the regular levels but some lines are heard over and over depending on the circumstances, the lines are there just to be there pretty much. It's not a very story driven game so you don't have to listen to a lot of voice acting.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

Overall it is a solid platformer if you are into repetitive gameplay similar to other games you have played just like Geometry Dash, Portal or any other game that requires you to do memorization. The fact that this game has its own look and design prevents it from being a complete copycat and it turned out to be fun when you give it a chance. I covered the entire regular levels this game has to offer and I have gameplay videos on my playthrough of it when I livestreamed it if you want to know what the experience was like.
